title.narrative: Promoting the translation of international human rights obligations and commitments into improved laws, policies and practices in developing countries

description.narrative: URG will elaborate guiding principles for the establishment and development of NMIRFs, conduct pilot projects in two developing countries to establish or strengthen NMIRFs, identify good practices with the national implementation of human rights recommendations and measure the impact on children’s and women’s rights in 10 developing countries, and conduct two capacity-building workshops for environmental human rights defenders in Africa and South-East Asia. URG will partner with OHCHR, UNFPA, UNICEF and UNEP. The key objective of the project is to promote the translation of international human rights obligations and commitments into improved national laws, policies and practices in developing countries. This will in turn help strengthen progress towards the achievement of the SDGs ‘leaving no one behind,’ the strengthening of democracy and rule of law, and the prevention of human rights crises and conflict.

organisation.narrative: Permanent Mission of Denmark to the UN in Geneva

mailing-address.narrative: Mission permanente du Danemark auprés de l'Office des Nations Unies à Genéve, 56 rue de Moillebeau, Case Postale 435

policy-marker.narrative: Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention on Biological Diversity
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Convention to Combat Desertification
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Adaptation
Aid Targeting the Objectives of the Framework Convention on Climate Change - Mitigation
Reproductive, Maternal, Newborn and Child Health (RMNCH)

title.narrative: - Organisation of at least 2 capacity-building workshops with UNEP - 1 in Africa and 1 in Southeast Asia. - Integration of a gender perspective in those workshops. - Further dissemination of upgraded environment-rights.org web-portal for EHRDs – in relevant national languages. - During the workshops, URG will receive testimonies from EHRDs in order to a) tell their story to the wider world (e.g. via short videos), and b) to showcase the contribution they make to the protection of the environment, to human rights, and to sustainable development. - One-day event in Geneva showcasing individual EHRDs and ‘telling their stores,’ including via the aforementioned videos.

target.value: - Organisation of 1 capacity-building workshop with UNEP in SE Asia. - Integration of a gender perspective into the workshop. as well as a focus on indigenous persons. - Collection during the workshop of testimonies from EHRDs that a) tell their story to the wider world (e.g. via short videos). and b) showcase the contribution they make to the protection of the environment. to human rights. and to sustainable development. - Further dissemination of upgraded environment-rights.org web-portal for EHRDs – in relevant national languages. - Publication of 1 policy report. ‘telling their story’ of individual EHRDs and showcasing their contribution to the protection of the environment. to human rights. and to sustainable development. - 1 event in Geneva for the screening of videos ‘telling the stories’ of EHRDs.

actual.value: - 3 capacity-building workshops organised in cooperation with UNEP and OHCHR, targeting EHRDs in Africa, South-East Asia and Latin America, and focussing on the different available avenues to access support, and to secure remedy and redress that are available to EHRDs (i.e., either via ICSOs, UN agencies and mechanisms, or bilateral embassies). - During the workshops several participants identified to provide recorded video testimony. These video testimonies from EHRDs will be collected in Q1 of 2022 to feature in a compilation video ‘telling the stories of EHRDs’. The stories will also be summarised in written form of a policy report showcasing EHRDs contribution to the protection of the environment and human rights.

target.value: - Organisation of 1 capacity-building workshop with UNEP in Africa. - Integration of a gender perspective into the workshop. as well as a focus on indigenous persons. - Collection. during the workshop. of testimonies from EHRDs that a) tell their story to the wider world (e.g. via short videos). and b) showcase the contribution they make to the protection of the environment. to human rights. and to sustainable development. - Further dissemination of upgraded environment-rights.org web-portal for EHRDs – in relevant national languages.

actual.value: - Due to COVID-19 it was not possible to organise the capacity-building workshop in Africa as foreseen. URG was however able to convene three online regional consultations with EHRDs: one in Africa, one in Latin America, and one in Asia-Pacific, to gather and share good practices in the protection of EHRDs and the promotion of their work. URG and UNEP integrated a gender perspective into the workshops, as well as a focus on indigenous persons. - Stories from EHRDs, including women EHRDs, presented on the environment-rights.org website under the title ‘You are not alone.’ - URG has also further disseminated and upgraded the environment-rights.org webportal for EHRDs – including in relevant national languages.

target.value: No defined targets for this year as project started in August.

title.narrative: Promote and support the elaboration of guiding principles for the establishment and development of national mechanisms for implementation, reporting and follow-up (NMIRFs)

- Secure ratification/endorsement of Pacific Island States for the ‘Pacific Principles’ on the establishment and functioning of NMIRFs. Launch and disseminate the Principles at the Human Rights Council and the GA. - Directly contribute (in cooperation with OHCHR) to 3 (Africa, Asia-Pacific and Latin America) of the 5 regional meetings launched by Council resolution 42/30 (exchanges of good practice with implementation amongst developing countries). - Present the ‘Pacific Principles’ during those 3 regional meetings, as a means of encouraging the elaboration of other sets of regional principles.

target.value: - Contribute to 1 of the regional meeting on NMIRFs under Council resolution 42/30. Use the meeting as a platform to identify and share good practice on implementation and reporting. and to begin to develop a further set of regional principles (like the ‘Pacific Principles’). - Secure the endorsement (i.e. ratification) of the ‘Pacific Principles’ by 8 of the 9 Pacific Island States. - Launch the ‘Pacific Principles’ with events in Geneva and New York.

actual.value: - The first regional meeting on NMIRFs under Council resolution 42/30 was delayed due to the COVID-19 pandemic. - The ‘Pacific Principles’ were endorsed by 8 of the 9 Pacific Island States. - Due to the COVID-19 pandemic it was decided to organise a joint Geneva-New York hybrid event to launch the ‘Pacific Principles’. This event took place at the Permanent Mission of Australia in the margins of HRC44.

target.value: No defined targets for this year as project started in August.

- Contribute to 2 further regional meetings on NMIRFs under Council resolution 42/30. Use these meetings as a platform to identify and share good practice on implementation and reporting. and to begin to develop 2 further sets of regional principles (like the ‘Pacific Principles’) on NMIRFs. - Promote these different sets of regional principles on NMIRFs in Geneva and New York.

actual.value: Progress reported per March 2022 (results will be updated by the end of project period) - The five regional meetings on NMIRFs under Council resolution 42/30, initially scheduled to take place in 2020-early 2021 took place online in November/December 2021. URG actively participated in the meetings and presented the ‘Pacific Principles’. - URG conducted a global survey of States to map the emergence and evolution of NMIRFs. Over 40 States have been surveyed. This survey will be included in a policy report to be published in the first quarter of 2022 and will provide a platform to further disseminate the Pacific Principles.

title.narrative: Track and identify good practices with the national implementation of human rights recommendations

- Work with UNICEF and UNFPA country offices in 10 developing countries (5 with UNICEF, 5 with UNFPA) to track - in detail - domestic progress with the implementation of child rights recommendations (in the case of UNICEF) and sexual and reproductive health rights recommendations (in the case of UNFPA) - Work with the concerned developing countries, as well as with UNICEF and UNFPA country offices, to apply output and outcome indicators to measure the impact of the implementation of these recommendations - Identification of good practice on the part of developing country governments (as well as, for example, parliamentarians), UN Country Teams and bilateral donors in supporting human rights implementation on the ground - Highlight ‘human rights stories’ – successful examples of where the UN human rights system has had a clear positive impact on the enjoyment of human rights

target.value: - 1 assessment (in cooperation with developing countries and UNFPA) of the implementation and impact of sexual and reproductive health and rights recommendations in 5 developing countries. together with identification of good practice case studies. and recommendations to other developing countries and international development partners.

actual.value: - MoU signed with UNFPA for the assessment of the implementation and impact of recommendations stemming from the UN human rights mechanisms related to sexual and reproductive health and rights. Six countries - Costa Rica, Côte d’Ivoire, Jordan, Kazakhstan, Kenya, and the Maldives (covering all 6 regions in which UNFPA is active) have been selected to function as case studies for the assessment. The quantitative (analysis of recommendations) and qualitative (case studies) have been finalised for 90%. The publication of the report currently scheduled for the end of Q1 of 2022.

target.value: - 1 assessment (in cooperation with developing countries and UNICEF) of the implementation and impact of child rights recommendations in 5 developing countries together with identification of good practice case studies and recommendations to other developing countries and international development partners.

actual.value: MoU signed with UNICEF for the assessment of the implementation and impact of child rights recommendations. One assessment of the implementation and impact of child rights recommendations, conducted in cooperation with UNICEF, finalised in November 2020 for 5 developing countries covering all UN regions and 1 developed country: Kyrgyzstan, Mongolia, Montenegro, South Africa, United Kingdom, and Uruguay.

target.value: No defined targets for this year as project started in August.

title.narrative: Pilot projects in 2 developing countries to help them establish/strengthen NMIRFs

- URG, in consultation with DK, will select 2 of the developing countries that have requested technical assistance/capacity-building support to establish or strengthen an NMIRF (e.g. Rwanda, Marshall Islands, Gambia, Zambia, Tanzania, Sudan, Ethiopia, Fiji, Maldives and Armenia). - URG will implement pilot capacity-building projects in cooperation with these 2 States - in Geneva and in-country (as it has already done with Georgia and Fiji) - to advise the government, parliamentarians, judges and lawyers, NHRIs and NGOs on the establishment/strengthening of inclusive and effective NMIRFs – based on the ‘Pacific Principles.’ The 2 capacity-building projects will be centred on the organisation of 2 in-country workshops with relevant national stakeholders. - Based on the experiences of these 2 pilot projects, URG could expand such efforts in the future to meet the growing demand from developing countries. - URG will work with the 2 relevant governments to install ‘IMPACT OSS’ software

target.value: - 1 capacity-building workshop in Africa or Asia covering government officials. parliamentarians. NHRIs and NGOs. - Installation of ‘IMPACT OSS’ or similar implementation-reporting software.

actual.value: - A two-day digital capacity building workshop for the RMI Human Rights Commission scheduled for late March 2022 with a focus on good practices identified through the NMRF survey and IMPACT OSS. - Given the developments in Ethiopia and Sudan, discussions continued with Fiji to organise a capacity building workshop with their AG’s office, who is currently analysing the possibility of establishing an NMIRF.

target.value: No defined targets for this year as project started in August.
- 1 capacity-building workshop in Africa. covering government officials. parliamentarians. NHRIs and NGOs. - Installation of ‘IMPACT OSS’ or similar implementation-reporting software.

actual.value: The first recipient of the capacity-building workshop for Africa to have been identified was Ethiopia. Unfortunately, due to the political instability and the conflict that erupted in the country in 2020 the collaboration with the country was terminated. In its place, URG had reached agreement with the new democratic government of Sudan to receive capacity-building and technical assistance. Partly as a result of such contacts, in early 2021, Sudan established a NMIRF. - Preparatory workshop with the Sudan Mission in Geneva conducted in January 2021. Preparation for an in-country workshop in Sudan suspended following the military takeover in October 2021.

title.narrative: Improved implementation of international human rights obligations and commitments in developing countries

- Improved implementation of international human rights obligations and commitments in developing countries. - Greater and more regularised involvement of parliamentarians, NHRIs and NGOs in human rights implementation, tracking and reporting. - Evidence of implementation and impact (via indicators) in developing countries, especially for children’s rights and women’s rights. - Evidence of the further benefits of implementation for progress towards the SDGs, the promotion of democracy, and the prevention of crises and conflicts. - 10 good practice case studies (with developing countries, UNICEF and UNFPA) showing the positive impact of implementation on women’s and children’s rights recommendations – on the domestic enjoyment of human rights.

target.value: - Agreement on different sets of regional principles for effective implementation and reporting (e.g. ‘Pacific Principles’). - Number of high standard NMIRFs in developing countries increases to over 50. - Reduction in reporting backlog in the developing countries chosen for capacity-building support under the pilot projects set out in the second output (see below). - National parliamentarians. NHRIs and NGOs more fully involved in human rights implementation in the developing countries chosen for capacity-building support under the pilot projects (see below). - 10 national ‘good practice’ case studies showing human rights implementation and impact in developing countries. especially for women’s rights and children’s rights.

title.narrative: Strengthening the protection and supporting the work of environmental human rights defenders

- Safer and more secure work environment for EHRDs – reduction in risk and vulnerability. - Reduction in stigmatisation of EHRDs as being ‘anti-development’ – and increased public recognition of their crucial role in sustainable development. - Better protection and promotion of the rights of vulnerable communities in the concerned developing countries (e.g. indigenous groups). - Protection of the natural environment and progress with mitigating/adapting to the effects of climate change. - Promotion and protection of women’s rights via a gendered focus on women human rights defenders.

target.value: Mitigation of the risks faced by EHRDs in developing countries. especially women EHRDs; greater understanding of the importance of their work for sustainable development and their particular vulnerabilities. especially amongst government officials and law enforcement agencies; and greater recognition of the work EHRDs to defend human rights. protect the environment. and address climate change.
